text.div:
Generated Narrative: StructureDefinition ext-R5-Composition.section

NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Extension 0..*Extension(4.0.1)Composition is broken into sections
Slices for extension 0..*ExtensionExtension
Slice: Unordered, Open by value:url
extension:title 0..1ExtensionLabel for section (e.g. for ToC)
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section.title"
value[x] 0..1stringLabel for section (e.g. for ToC)
extension:code 0..1ExtensionClassification of section (recommended)
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section.code"
value[x] 0..1CodeableConceptClassification of section (recommended)
Binding: http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/ValueSet/ValueSet-R5-doc-section-codes-for-R4 (example): Classification of a section of a composition/document.
extension:author 0..*ExtensionWho and/or what authored the section
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section.author"
value[x] 0..1Reference(Cross-version Profile for R5.Practitioner for use in FHIR R4(0.0.1-snapshot-3) | Practitioner | Cross-version Profile for R5.PractitionerRole for use in FHIR R4(0.0.1-snapshot-3) | PractitionerRole | Cross-version Profile for R5.Device for use in FHIR R4(0.0.1-snapshot-3) | Device | Cross-version Profile for R5.Patient for use in FHIR R4(0.0.1-snapshot-3) | Patient | Cross-version Profile for R5.RelatedPerson for use in FHIR R4(0.0.1-snapshot-3) | RelatedPerson | Cross-version Profile for R5.Organization for use in FHIR R4(0.0.1-snapshot-3) | Organization)Who and/or what authored the section
extension:focus 0..1ExtensionWho/what the section is about, when it is not about the subject of composition
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section.focus"
value[x] 0..1Reference(Cross-version Profile for R5.Resource for use in FHIR R4(0.0.1-snapshot-3) | Resource)Who/what the section is about, when it is not about the subject of composition
extension:text 0..1ExtensionText summary of the section, for human interpretation
Slices for extension 0..*ExtensionExtension
Slice: Unordered, Open by value:url
extension:_datatype 1..1ExtensionDataType slice for a FHIR R5 `Narrative` value
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/_datatype"
value[x] 1..1stringValue of extension
Fixed Value: Narrative
extension:status 1..1Extensiongenerated | extensions | additional | empty
url 1..1uri"status"
value[x] 1..1codegenerated | extensions | additional | empty
Binding: http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/ValueSet/ValueSet-R5-narrative-status-for-R4 (required): The status of a resource narrative.
extension:div 1..1ExtensionLimited xhtml content
url 1..1uri"div"
value[x] 1..1uriLimited xhtml content
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section.text"
value[x] 0..0Value of extension
extension:orderedBy 0..1ExtensionOrder of section entries
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section.orderedBy"
value[x] 0..1CodeableConceptOrder of section entries
Binding: http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/ValueSet/ValueSet-R5-list-order-for-R4 (preferred): What order applies to the items in the entry.
extension:entry 0..*ExtensionA reference to data that supports this section
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section.entry"
value[x] 0..1Reference(Cross-version Profile for R5.Resource for use in FHIR R4(0.0.1-snapshot-3) | Resource)A reference to data that supports this section
extension:emptyReason 0..1ExtensionWhy the section is empty
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section.emptyReason"
value[x] 0..1CodeableConceptWhy the section is empty
Binding: http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/ValueSet/ValueSet-R5-list-empty-reason-for-R4 (preferred): If a section is empty, why it is empty.
extension:section 0..*ExtensionNested Section
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section"
value[x] 0..0Value of extension
url 1..1uri"http://hl7.org/fhir/5.0/StructureDefinition/extension-Composition.section"
value[x] 0..0Value of extension

Documentation for this format

name: ExtensionComposition_Section
title: Cross-version Extension `R5.Composition.section` for use in FHIR R4
description: This cross-version extension represents the FHIR R5 element `Composition.section` for use in FHIR R4.
purpose:
This extension is part of the cross-version definitions generated to enable use of the
element `Composition.section` as defined in FHIR R5
in FHIR R4.

The source element is defined as:
`Composition.section` 0..* `BackboneElement`

Across FHIR versions, the element set has been mapped as:
*  R5: `Composition.section` 0..* `BackboneElement`
*  R4B: `Composition.section` 0..* `BackboneElement`
*  R4: `Composition.section` 0..* `BackboneElement`

Following are the generation technical comments:
Element `Composition.section` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section`.

element.definition: The root of the sections that make up the composition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: An Extension

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The label for this particular section.  This will be part of the rendered content for the document, and is often used to build a table of contents.
element.comment: The title identifies the section for a human reader. The title must be consistent with the narrative of the resource that is the target of the section.content reference. Generally, sections SHOULD have titles, but in some documents, it is unnecessary or inappropriate. Typically, this is where a section has subsections that have their own adequately distinguishing title,  or documents that only have a single section. Most Implementation Guides will make section title to be a required element.
element.requirements:
Section headings are often standardized for different types of documents.  They give guidance to humans on how the document is organized. Element `Composition.section.title` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.title` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.title`.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

element.definition: The label for this particular section.  This will be part of the rendered content for the document, and is often used to build a table of contents.
element.comment: The title identifies the section for a human reader. The title must be consistent with the narrative of the resource that is the target of the section.content reference. Generally, sections SHOULD have titles, but in some documents, it is unnecessary or inappropriate. Typically, this is where a section has subsections that have their own adequately distinguishing title,  or documents that only have a single section. Most Implementation Guides will make section title to be a required element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A code identifying the kind of content contained within the section. This must be consistent with the section title.
element.comment:
The code identifies the section for an automated processor of the document. This is particularly relevant when using profiles to control the structure of the document.   

If the section has content (instead of sub-sections), the section.code does not change the meaning or interpretation of the resource that is the content of the section in the comments for the section.code.
element.requirements:
Provides computable standardized labels to topics within the document. Element `Composition.section.code` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.code` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.code`.

If the section has content (instead of sub-sections), the section.code does not change the meaning or interpretation of the resource that is the content of the section in the comments for the section.code.

binding.description: Classification of a section of a composition/document.

element.short: Who and/or what authored the section
element.definition: Identifies who is responsible for the information in this section, not necessarily who typed it in.
element.requirements:
Identifies who is responsible for the content. Element `Composition.section.author` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.author` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.author`.

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension

element.short: Who and/or what authored the section
element.definition: Identifies who is responsible for the information in this section, not necessarily who typed it in.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who/what the section is about, when it is not about the subject of composition
element.definition: The actual focus of the section when it is not the subject of the composition, but instead represents something or someone associated with the subject such as (for a patient subject) a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. If not focus is specified, the focus is assumed to be focus of the parent section, or, for a section in the Composition itself, the subject of the composition. Sections with a focus SHALL only include resources where the logical subject (patient, subject, focus, etc.) matches the section focus, or the resources have no logical subject (few resources).
element.comment: Typically, sections in a doument are about the subject of the document, whether that is a  patient, or group of patients, location, or device, or whatever. For some kind of documents, some sections actually contain data about related entities. Typical examples are  a section in a newborn discharge summary concerning the mother, or family history documents, with a section about each family member, though there are many other examples.
element.requirements:
Element `Composition.section.focus` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.focus` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.focus`.

If not focus is specified, the focus is assumed to be focus of the parent section, or, for a section in the Composition itself, the subject of the composition. For some kind of documents, some sections actually contain data about related entities. Typical examples are  a section in a newborn discharge summary concerning the mother, or family history documents, with a section about each family member, though there are many other examples.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the section, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains the attested content of the section, used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative.
element.comment: Document profiles may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.requirements:
Element `Composition.section.text` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.text` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.text`.

element.definition: The actual narrative content, a stripped down version of XHTML.
element.comment: The contents of the html element are an XHTML fragment containing only the basic html formatting elements described in chapters 7-11 and 15 of the HTML 4.0 standard, <a> elements (either name or href), images and internally contained stylesheets. The XHTML content SHALL NOT contain a head, a body, external stylesheet references, scripts, forms, base/link/xlink, frames, iframes and objects.

element.definition: Specifies the order applied to the items in the section entries.
element.comment: Applications SHOULD render ordered lists in the order provided, but MAY allow users to re-order based on their own preferences as well. If there is no order specified, the order is unknown, though there may still be some order.
element.requirements:
Important for presentation and rendering.  Lists may be sorted to place more important information first or to group related entries. Element `Composition.section.orderedBy` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.orderedBy` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.orderedBy`.

element.comment: If there are no entries in the list, an emptyReason SHOULD be provided.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: If the section is empty, why the list is empty. An empty section typically has some text explaining the empty reason.
element.comment: The various reasons for an empty section make a significant interpretation to its interpretation. Note that this code is for use when the entire section content has been suppressed, and not for when individual items are omitted - implementers may consider using a text note or a flag on an entry in these cases.
element.requirements:
Allows capturing things like "none exist" or "not asked" which can be important for most lists. Element `Composition.section.emptyReason` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.emptyReason` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.emptyReason`.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: The root of the sections that make up the composition.
The label for this particular section.  This will be part of the rendered content for the document, and is often used to build a table of contents.
element.comment: The title identifies the section for a human reader. The title must be consistent with the narrative of the resource that is the target of the section.content reference. Generally, sections SHOULD have titles, but in some documents, it is unnecessary or inappropriate. Typically, this is where a section has subsections that have their own adequately distinguishing title,  or documents that only have a single section. Most Implementation Guides will make section title to be a required element.
element.requirements:
Section headings are often standardized for different types of documents.  They give guidance to humans on how the document is organized. Element `Composition.section.title` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.title` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.title`.

element.definition: The label for this particular section.  This will be part of the rendered content for the document, and is often used to build a table of contents.
element.comment: The title identifies the section for a human reader. The title must be consistent with the narrative of the resource that is the target of the section.content reference. Generally, sections SHOULD have titles, but in some documents, it is unnecessary or inappropriate. Typically, this is where a section has subsections that have their own adequately distinguishing title,  or documents that only have a single section. Most Implementation Guides will make section title to be a required element.

element.definition: A code identifying the kind of content contained within the section. This must be consistent with the section title.
element.comment:
The code identifies the section for an automated processor of the document. This is particularly relevant when using profiles to control the structure of the document.   

If the section has content (instead of sub-sections), the section.code does not change the meaning or interpretation of the resource that is the content of the section in the comments for the section.code.
element.requirements:
Provides computable standardized labels to topics within the document. Element `Composition.section.code` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.code` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.code`.

element.definition: A code identifying the kind of content contained within the section. This must be consistent with the section title.
element.comment:
The code identifies the section for an automated processor of the document. This is particularly relevant when using profiles to control the structure of the document.   

If the section has content (instead of sub-sections), the section.code does not change the meaning or interpretation of the resource that is the content of the section in the comments for the section.code.

binding.description: Classification of a section of a composition/document.

element.short: Who and/or what authored the section
element.definition: Identifies who is responsible for the information in this section, not necessarily who typed it in.
element.requirements:
Identifies who is responsible for the content. Element `Composition.section.author` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.author` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.author`.

element.short: Who and/or what authored the section
element.definition: Identifies who is responsible for the information in this section, not necessarily who typed it in.

element.short: Who/what the section is about, when it is not about the subject of composition
element.definition: The actual focus of the section when it is not the subject of the composition, but instead represents something or someone associated with the subject such as (for a patient subject) a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. If not focus is specified, the focus is assumed to be focus of the parent section, or, for a section in the Composition itself, the subject of the composition. Sections with a focus SHALL only include resources where the logical subject (patient, subject, focus, etc.) matches the section focus, or the resources have no logical subject (few resources).
element.comment: Typically, sections in a doument are about the subject of the document, whether that is a  patient, or group of patients, location, or device, or whatever. For some kind of documents, some sections actually contain data about related entities. Typical examples are  a section in a newborn discharge summary concerning the mother, or family history documents, with a section about each family member, though there are many other examples.
element.requirements:
Element `Composition.section.focus` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.focus` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.focus`.

element.short: Who/what the section is about, when it is not about the subject of composition
element.definition: The actual focus of the section when it is not the subject of the composition, but instead represents something or someone associated with the subject such as (for a patient subject) a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. If not focus is specified, the focus is assumed to be focus of the parent section, or, for a section in the Composition itself, the subject of the composition. Sections with a focus SHALL only include resources where the logical subject (patient, subject, focus, etc.) matches the section focus, or the resources have no logical subject (few resources).
element.comment: Typically, sections in a doument are about the subject of the document, whether that is a  patient, or group of patients, location, or device, or whatever. For some kind of documents, some sections actually contain data about related entities. Typical examples are  a section in a newborn discharge summary concerning the mother, or family history documents, with a section about each family member, though there are many other examples.

element.short: Text summary of the section, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains the attested content of the section, used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative.
element.comment: Document profiles may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.requirements:
Element `Composition.section.text` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.text` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.text`.

element.short: DataType slice for a FHIR R5 `Narrative` value
element.definition: Slice to indicate the presence of a R5 `Narrative` in FHIR R4

element.comment: Must be: Narrative

element.definition: The status of the narrative - whether it's entirely generated (from just the defined data or the extensions too), or whether a human authored it and it may contain additional data.
element.requirements: Element `Narrative.status` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Narrative.status`.

element.definition: The status of the narrative - whether it's entirely generated (from just the defined data or the extensions too), or whether a human authored it and it may contain additional data.

binding.description: The status of a resource narrative.

element.definition: The actual narrative content, a stripped down version of XHTML.
element.comment: The contents of the html element are an XHTML fragment containing only the basic html formatting elements described in chapters 7-11 and 15 of the HTML 4.0 standard, <a> elements (either name or href), images and internally contained stylesheets. The XHTML content SHALL NOT contain a head, a body, external stylesheet references, scripts, forms, base/link/xlink, frames, iframes and objects.
element.requirements: Element `Narrative.div` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Narrative.div`.

element.definition: The actual narrative content, a stripped down version of XHTML.
element.comment: The contents of the html element are an XHTML fragment containing only the basic html formatting elements described in chapters 7-11 and 15 of the HTML 4.0 standard, <a> elements (either name or href), images and internally contained stylesheets. The XHTML content SHALL NOT contain a head, a body, external stylesheet references, scripts, forms, base/link/xlink, frames, iframes and objects.

element.definition: Specifies the order applied to the items in the section entries.
element.comment: Applications SHOULD render ordered lists in the order provided, but MAY allow users to re-order based on their own preferences as well. If there is no order specified, the order is unknown, though there may still be some order.
element.requirements:
Important for presentation and rendering.  Lists may be sorted to place more important information first or to group related entries. Element `Composition.section.orderedBy` is part of an existing definition because parent element `Composition.section` requires a component extension (e.g., if this element is used as a content reference).
Element `Composition.section.orderedBy` is mapped to FHIR R4 element `Composition.section.orderedBy`.

binding.description: What order applies to the items in the entry.

element.short: A reference to data that supports this section
element.definition: A reference to the actual resource from which the narrative in the section is derived.
